From 19:11Z to 19:35Z (24 minutes) there was an outage to some Bitly services.

During this outage the Bitly website (bitly.com) and our API intermittently returned 5xx errors due to an impact to some servers behind our load balancer.

incidents.name: Errors when shortening a link from the Bitly web application

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results. Link shortening is functioning again from https://app.bitly.com
The issue has been identified and we are applying mitigations to restore affected services

Hi, community. We’re seeing early indications of increased errors impacting shortening links for logged-in users on https://app.bitly.com. We’re looking into this now and will share an update within 30 minutes.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.

Hi community. We’re seeing early indications of impact to our logged-in website for our user base. API requests and Bitly redirects should be functioning as normal. We’re looking into this now and will share an update within 30 minutes.

Google Cloud experienced an [outage with their Global Load Balancing \(GLB\) service](https://status.cloud.google.com/incidents/6PM5mNd43NbMqjCZ5REh) which affected Bitly services globally for 22 minutes from `17:48Z` to `18:10Z` \( `12:48pm` - `1:10pm` US Eastern Time\) on Nov 16th.  
  
During this outage the Bitly website \([bitly.com](http://bitly.com)\) and our API returned HTTP 404 \(page not found\) responses and users were unable to create new links.  
  
Existing links on `bit.ly` and Custom Domains configured with a DNS `CNAME` record were briefly impacted while automatic mitigations took effect but continued to function. Custom Domains configured with DNS `A` records were impacted and returned 404 responses.

We apologize for the inconvenience this outage has caused and understand the impact to our customers. We place a high value on the reliability of our service and are evaluating ways to improve our ability to mitigate this type of issue.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our November 16th incident: https://stspg.io/g9xmw9kq1gmj

incidents.name: Degraded API impacting some link creation

incident_updates.body:
From `22:27 UTC` until `23:17 UTC` on Oct 27, 2021 some API requests to create new links failed with a `HTTP 500` or a `HTTP 503` response. API Clients that implemented retry may have succeeded on subsequent attempts.  
  
**Root Cause:** A new database ACL change was released which contained an invalid permission setting. This permission setting took priority over existing settings and blocked new database connections causing a progressive increase in application failures as applications opened new connections. The invalid configuration was identified and removed.  
  
We understand the availability to create links is important to our customers and have planned work to prevent this impact in the future by improving how changes like this are processed and validated and by improving our ability to quickly rollback database ACL changes.
The incident has been resolved.
We are currently investigating this issue.
This incident has been resolved.
We've identified an issue affecting creating custom links and are working to resolve.

Starting at 09:43 UTC there was an elevated error rate affecting some API requests due to a database failure. Normal service was restored at 09:51 UTC.

A configuration error related to deprecation of an unrelated API endpoint incorrectly affected API calls to `POST /v4/custom_bitlinks` causing them to error with a HTTP 500 response in some circumstances .  
  
From `2020-08-17` through `2020-09-13` this caused 5.4% of API requests to error.   
From `2020-09-14 00:00 UTC` through `2020-09-14 21:26 UTC` all requests errored.
This incident has been resolved.

Good news, community: if you were impacted by the earlier issues on our /v4/custom_bitlinks API, you should now be able to use these endpoints without any problems. Thanks for bearing with us! For more info on this incident please see our status page: status.bitly.com

We are seeing early indications that we are currently the targets of a denial of service attack which may cause performance degradation.  There may be disruptions to Bitly services for the next few minutes.  We have reached out to our providers and are working with them to mitigate the attack as quickly as possible.

From 8/6/2020 22:30 UTC until 22:43 UTC (13 minutes) requests to bitly.com experienced increased latency and/or timeouts. During the same timeframe there was a small secondary impact in error rates to API endpoints affecting 0.1% of API requests.

Hi community. We’re currently investigating reports of web and API performance impacting much of our user base. We apologize if this is causing trouble for you. We’ll be sure to update you as soon as we know more!

Between 0910 and 0932 Friday 6/21 UTC, one of our data center providers had a planned maintenance window. There should have been no impact to our services, but this maintenance caused a degradation of performance for our API and Website.

During this time redirects were completely unaffected and performed as normal. Metrics collection continued to function throughout and no data was lost.

As a result, our engineering team is accelerating existing plans to remove our production system dependency on this data center in order to prevent future outages of this type.
This incident has been resolved.

Good news, community: if you were impacted by the earlier website and api issues, you should now be able to access our services without any problems. Thanks for bearing with us! For more info on this incident please see our status page: status.bitly.com

Hi community. We’re seeing early indications of degraded performance impacting our APIs and Website for some of our user base. We’re looking into this now and will share an update within 30 minutes.

Between 23:13 Monday and 01:14 Tuesday UTC, a networking provider that maintains a high bandwidth connection between our two primary data centers suffered a complete outage that resulted in some of Bitly’s production systems being unable to talk to one another and service requests. While we maintain multiple connections for redundancy, all  connections flowed through a facility that suffered a widespread power failure.

During this time, [bit.ly](https://bit.ly/) redirects and some Custom Domain redirects were unaffected. However, the website and API were down and Custom Domain redirects were seriously degraded. Metrics collection continued to function throughout and no data was lost.

We apologize for the inconvenience this outage has caused and understand the impact to our customers. Our engineering team is accelerating existing plans to remove our production dependency on this data center network connection in order to prevent future outages of this type.

Good news: We've completed testing our provider's networking issue and we're confident that they've implemented a fix. If you were impacted, things should now be resolved. If you’re still experiencing issues, please email support@bit.ly so we can look into the root cause of your problem.

incidents.name: bitly.com is not loading for logged in users

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are currently investigating this issue.
This incident has been resolved.
We are continuing to monitor for any further issues.
We have identified a DDoS attack and have implemented mitigation. We are monitoring the situation.

Based on the best information that we and our providers have available, we believe that this round of DDoS attacks has stopped.

Accordingly we are returning to normal operations and all users should be able to access Bitly services without any issues.

If you encounter any problems connecting to Bitly services, please [contact support](http://support.bitly.com).

Thank you for your patience during this incident.  We will be posting a post-mortem with details of the incident and our response within the next few days.

Based on the best information that we and our providers have available, we believe that this round of DDoS attacks has stopped.

Accordingly we are returning to normal operations and all users should be able to access Bitly services without any issues.

If you encounter any problems connecting to Bitly services, please [contact support](http://support.bitly.com).

Thank you for your patience during this incident.  We will be posting a post-mortem with details of the incident and our response within the next few days.

We have worked with our network providers and have put mitigation measures in place to limit the impact of an on-going denial of service attack.

While mitigation measures are in place most users should be able to access Bitly services without issue, but some users, especially those connecting via VPNs, proxies, or large corporate networks may experience some issues.

Please contact [Bitly support](http://support.bitly.com/) if you are experiencing problem and we can work with you to try and resolve any issues as quickly as possible.

We expect to remain under mitigation for at least the next few hours depending on the duration and frequency of follow-on attacks.

Updates will be provided as we learn more and when we believe the attack is over.
This incident has been resolved.
We've blocked the attack and are continuing to monitor.
We're currently mitigating a distributed denial of service attack that is causing degraded performance to our API and website. Redirects and metric systems are unaffected.
